sections.title: Dental fillings in Shoreham-by-Sea
sections.body: Clinician-led repairs with clear guidance on when composite or amalgam serves you best.
bullets: Composite or amalgam matched to bite forces and moisture control
Bonded placement to strengthen the seal and reduce leakage
Careful shaping for smooth contacts and a balanced bite

sections.title: Restorations placed for longevity and comfort
items: Balanced advice on composite versus amalgam for your specific tooth
Amalgams bonded to improve strength and marginal seal when indicated
Moisture control and isolation to help the restoration last
Bite checks to keep opposing teeth protected
Clear aftercare so sensitivity settles predictably

sections.title: Choosing the right filling material for your tooth
sections.body: Composite (tooth-coloured) fillings bond to enamel and dentine, allowing conservative shaping and a natural finish. Amalgam fillings remain highly durable in areas with heavy load or where moisture control is limited. We bond amalgams to improve strength and the seal when we use them.
bullets: Composite: blends with your tooth, good for precise shaping
Amalgam: strong under heavy bite or limited isolation
We advise when each option best protects the tooth
For large defects we may suggest onlays/inlays or crowns
Root canal therapy is discussed if decay reaches the nerve

sections.title: Steady repairs for everyday and heavily loaded teeth
items: New cavities caught early before more extensive work is needed
Replacing worn, fractured, or leaking fillings
Areas with limited dryness where amalgam is safer
Teeth carrying high bite forces or heavy contact points
Restorations that support onlay, crown, or endodontic planning

sections.title: Comfortable, well-isolated placement
items: Numbing and isolation to keep the area comfortable and dry
Removal of decay or old material with minimal healthy tooth loss
Liners or bonding steps based on depth and sensitivity
Placement of composite or bonded amalgam with controlled layering
Careful shaping and polishing for smooth contacts
Bite check and adjustments so it feels natural
sections.strapline: We explain each stage and pause if you need breaks.

sections.title: Helping your filling settle
items: Mild sensitivity to temperature or bite is common for a few days
Avoid very hard or sticky foods on the tooth for the first 24 hours
Keep to daily brushing and interdental cleaning around the margins
Contact us if pain persists, the bite feels high, or you notice cracks
Regular reviews help us monitor wear, bruxism, and gum health

sections.title: What influences how long fillings last
sections.body: Bite forces, diet, and parafunction all affect how a filling wears. Composite and amalgam both last longer with good moisture control at placement, balanced occlusion, and supportive hygiene care.
bullets: Bite force and grinding patterns (consider splints if needed)
Diet, sugar exposure, and acid challenges
Home care and professional hygiene visits
Size and location of the restoration
Routine check-ups to spot early changes

sections.title: When a filling needs extra support
sections.body: If the tooth is heavily broken down or the nerve is affected, we guide you through the next restorative steps.

sections.title: Keeping the restored tooth healthy
sections.body: Regular hygiene visits and gum care keep the margins clean and reduce the risk of future decay around a filling. We plan maintenance intervals based on your gum health and any bruxism or diet risks.
bullets: Hygiene and gum care to protect the edges
Monitoring for cracks, leakage, or wear
Occlusal splints for clenching or grinding
Check-ups to time replacements before problems escalate
Advice on diet and home care around restorations

faqs.question: When is amalgam better than composite?
faqs.answer: We consider amalgam when the tooth takes heavy load, when isolation is difficult, or when longevity is the priority. We bond amalgams to enhance strength and seal.

faqs.question: How long will sensitivity last?
faqs.answer: Mild temperature or bite sensitivity can last a few days. Let us know if it persists beyond a week or if pain wakes you at night.

faqs.question: What happens during the appointment?
faqs.answer: We numb the tooth, isolate it, remove decay or failing material, bond the new filling, shape and polish it, and check the bite before you leave.

faqs.question: When do you recommend an onlay or crown?
faqs.answer: If too much tooth is missing for a filling to hold safely, we may plan an onlay or crown to reinforce the structure and seal the tooth.
